p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE LINCOLN BULLETIN NO. 103 AGRICULTURAL STATISTICS NEBRASKA 1919 CO-OPERATIVE CROP REPORTING SERVICE United States State of Nebraska DEFT. OF AGRICULTURE DEPT. OF AGRICULTURE Bureau of Crop Estimates Leo stuhr. Secretary L. M. Estabrook, Chief Bureau of Market* £ Marketing A. E. Anderson, Field Agent George Williams, Chief

Leo Stuhr, Secretary of Agriculture. Sir: The work of gathering and compiling the Agricultural Statistics of the State of. Nebraska has in past years been carried on by the Nebraska State Board of Agriculture. By act of the 1919 Legislature the work was placed in the Department of Agriculture and in the organization of that .Department, was assigned to the Bureau of Markets and Market - ing. The figures and conclusions submitted are based upon data gathered by the assessors, together with information supplied by the corps of Federal and State Crop Reporters located in every part of the state and who are very closely identified with practical agriculture. It is not claimed that the results are entirely accurate and exact, yet for all practical pur - poses they are quite dependable and, without question, the most reliable information that can be secured from any source now available. In the matter of live stock, the conclusions reached are based entirely upon assessed valuations as reported by the precinct assessors. This seemed to be the only process by which satifactory results could be obtained, as it would not be consistent to arbitrarily fix an average value without respect to age and condition. One county (Keith) failed to report and the report from one (Boyd) was lost in transit, consequently the figures for these two counties are only approximate and are based on the returns of the previous year, together with such data as was secured from local crop reporters. Much more can be accomplished in making these statistics complete if the full cooperation of precinct assessors and county officials could be secured. I take the liberty of recommending that diligent effort be made to acquaint precinct assesors with the responsibilities of their work and the importance of faithful service in meeting the requirements of the law. Reliable statistics are invaluable in the matter of state publicity. It should be a subject of great concern to every citizen of the state, not alone that we may have a knowledge of these things ourselves, but that we may be able to present to the people of other states, in interesting and dependable form, the data reflecting the great agricultural possi - bilities and achievements of the state. • Credit is due Mr. A. E. Anderson of the Federal Bureau of Crop Estimates, also Miss H. Ferne Peck, State Seed Analyst, both of whom have rendered valuable service_ in the work of gathering and compiling these statistics, making it possible for the Department to render a report so interesting and complete. Geo. A. Williams, Chief, Bureau of Markets & Marketing.

NEBRASKA CROP REPORTER 62 The following statement, showing the working of the State Hail Insurance Law for the year 1919, was prepared at the request of the Agricultural Department, by J. E. Hart, Secretary of the Department of Trade and Commerce, and included herewith as an interesting and valu - able addition to this statistical report: An analysis of hail losses and premiums as shown by reports on file in the Hail Department, discloses some surprises in the ditribution of the losses and the sentiment existing among the farmers as to hail in - surance. In Zone Number 1, consisting of 41 eastern counties in the state, a rate of 25 cents per acre for $10.00 insurance and a rate of 40 cents per acre for $15.00 insurance on growing crops produced $202,584.44 in premiums and in the same counties losses 'were adjusted amounting to $164,785.64. In this zone premiums exceeded losses by $34,798.80. The counties showing the larger excesses in premiums were Clay, Fillmore, Polk and York, in the order named. In this zone Dixon County is in a class by itself and did not show either premium or loss. Thirteen coun - ties paid a total of $31,829.98 in premiums and have no claims for loss. Thayer County proved to be the banner county in the loss column and leads all competitors with a total of $117,783.66 and cost the Hail Department $104,351.37 more than all premiums collected in that county. Four other counties, Douglas, Lancaster, Pawnee and Pierce reported ■losses in excess of premiums collected. In Zone Number 2, consisting of 25 counties in central Nebraska, premiums were reported amounting to $311,021.59 and losses totaling $218,072.45, leaving a balance to the good, of $92,949.14. The big revenue producers in this zone were Adams, Kearney, Phelps, Webstor, Fumas and Harlan, in the order named. The big losses were claimed in Dawson, Custer, Buffalo and Gosper, in the order named. Six counties in this zone reported premiums smount - ing to $23,028. 16 and made no claims for loss. The rates in this zone were 40 cents and 60 cents per acre and proved ample to care for the losses. . The third zone proved to be the scene of the most destructive storms and in the 27 counties in the west end of the state, loss claims were filed totaling $307,313.42, as against premiums reported totaling $267,627.64, leaving a defiicit of $39,685.78. The large contributions to this defiicit were Chase, Lincoln, Fron - tier, McPherson, Keith and Red Willow Counties. The rates in this zone were 60 cents and 90 cents and this report would indicate that this was not sufficient to take care of the loss ratio. - ■ Grant County did not report insurance at all. The largest volume of business was written in Cheyenne County, with Phelps County in second place. - - The average loss for the state was 88.7 per cent of the premiums. Some adjustments that may change these estimates slightly are not yet completed. In explanation of the rates, plans and expenses in connection with the State Hail Insurance Department, it should be said in justice that the county organizations are entitled to .a great deal of the credit for the success of the entire proposition. Blank applications are prepared and sent out to the County Clerks in the several counties, where they are placed in the hands of the precinct and township assessor, and the risks are solicited, the policy written and mailed out to the insured, without any expense -whatever to the State Hail Department." The premiums are certified to the several county treasurers, assessed and collected as premium tax, also without expense to the Hail Department. The only considerable expense to which the Department is put, is the preparing of blanks, the expense of adjustment, department r erk hire, postage and other incidental expenses.
